title: Ain't That a Lot of Love
text:
"(Ain't That) a Lot of Love" is a 1966 song written by <a href="Homer%20Banks">Homer Banks</a> and Willia Dean Parker, and first released by Banks on <a href="Minit%20Records">Minit Records</a>, titled "A Lot of Love".
Simply Red version.
In 1999, British <a href="soul%20music">soul</a> and <a href="pop%20music">pop</a> band <a href="Simply%20Red">Simply Red</a> made a cover of "Ain't That a Lot of Love". It was released as the first single from their seventh studio album, "<a href="Love%20and%20the%20Russian%20Winter">Love and the Russian Winter</a>" and reached the Top 20 in Iceland, Scotland and the UK. On the <a href="Eurochart%20Hot%20100">Eurochart Hot 100</a>, it peaked at number 28. Remixes by <a href="Club%2069">Club 69</a> and <a href="Phats%20%26amp%3B%20Small">Phats & Small</a> were released as bonus tracks on a 2008 Special Edition of the album. A black-and-white <a href="music%20video">music video</a> was made for the song, directed by Mike Lipscombe. The same year, Welsh singer <a href="Tom%20Jones%20%28singer%29">Tom Jones</a> covered the song with Simply Red on his 1999 duet album, "<a href="Reload%20%28Tom%20Jones%20album%29">Reload</a>".
Critical reception.
James Poletti from "<a href="Dotmusic">Dotmusic</a>" wrote that the song "is a similarly <a href="house%20music">house</a>-influenced production", like "<a href="Fairground%20%28song%29">Fairground</a>". He added that it "is indebted to the popular late 90s prototype laid down by <a href="Stardust%20%28band%29">Stardust</a>'s '<a href="Music%20Sounds%20Better%20with%20You">Music Sounds Better with You</a>'. The connection isn't as directly obvious this time but the song is built around that kind of groove." "<a href="Florida%20Today">Florida Today</a>" said it "conjures up a flash of magic". John Terlesky from "<a href="The%20Morning%20Call">The Morning Call</a> "stated, "Its rhythmic hooks and catchy chorus, tarted up with <a href="techno">techno</a> trappings, stand out" of the other songs of the <a href="Love%20and%20the%20Russian%20Winter">album</a>.
